maml:description.maml:para: Allows user to choose a CSV file to export to his local machine.

When the function is called, an open file dialog box appears prompting the user to choose a file. Once a file is chosen, a second box appears prompting the user to select a folder to ouput to. This CMDlet is designed to be run from a script that is custom configured for each user. The -DisplayName parameter MUST BE UNIQUE to that person's session or else the CMDlet will not work.
Sets the initial directory that the file browser dialog box will open to. From there the user can select the file to export.
Sets the folder that the file will be exported to. Should be something like \tsclient\c\output.
This will describe the transfer and should be unique to that particular job, since it's a BITS transfer job.
This should also be a unique identifying string that you will use to cancel the job if need be using remove-bitstransfer.
Sets the initial directory that the file browser dialog box will open to. From there the user can select the file to export.
Sets the folder that the file will be exported to. Should be something like \tsclient\c\output.
This will describe the transfer and should be unique to that particular job, since it's a BITS transfer job.
This should also be a unique identifying string that you will use to cancel the job if need be using remove-bitstransfer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command directs the user to the "D:\RPG" folder so that he may choose a file for export. The folder browser windows will open up with \tsclient\c\output as its root and the user will be allowed to choose what folder he wants to put the file in. The transfer job will be called "Steve" and its description is "Steve's Transfer".

maml:description.maml:para: Gets errors from error variable $logerrorvariable and puts them into a text file that buffers up to 300 lines.
When this function is called, it looks for what's in $logerror and outputs everything in the array to a text file called $logfile.
Use this to name the error variable that you want to use for your function. If you're running a function that uses BITS, then name your error variable BITSerror.
Use this to create a folder that the log file will reside in. Always choose a default place like c:\logs for your error handling, since each job's log file will be named something different.
This will give each log file you create a unique name. If you run multiple jobs with the same log file name, they will be ordered by date, and only 300 lines are kept in the file.
Use this to name the error variable that you want to use for your function. If you're running a function that uses BITS, then name your error variable BITSerror.
Use this to create a folder that the log file will reside in. Always choose a default place like c:\logs for your error handling, since each job's log file will be named something different.
This will give each log file you create a unique name. If you run multiple jobs with the same log file name, they will be ordered by date, and only 300 lines are kept in the file.

dev:remarks.maml:para: "logerror" can be anything you want the errorvariable to be. However, this must be used in conjunction with the common parameter -errorvariable in whatever command you're trying to log errors from.

maml:description.maml:para: Installs Chocolatey on the operating system.
Invokes a script pulled from Chocolatey.org and installs Chocolatey and its dependencies, like 7z and dot net 4.
Installs dot net 4.5 via chocolatey.

Pulls dot net 4.5 install routine from chocolatey and checks first to see if dot net is already installed. If it is, it doesn't run. If it isn't, then the routine runs and the user will have to restart the computer before the changes take effect. It's the same as a silent install.
Installs mappoint 2006.
Requires access to the mappoint 2006 files. Checks operating system to see if mappoint is already installed and if not, it silently installs the software.
This is the location of the mappoint installation files.
This is the location of the mappoint installation files.

dev:remarks.maml:para: goes to the q: drive and attempts to install mappoint from q:\map2006\mappoint\msmap\data.msi. If it fails, it logs an error in c:\mappointlog.txt

maml:description.maml:para: Install Report Viewer 2012.
Uses Chocolatey.
Silently installs SQL 2012 CLR Types.
Uses Chocolatey.
Silently installs Windows Management Framework 3.0 using chocolatey.
for 32-bit or 64-bit operating systems running Windows Server 2008 or Windows Vista. Will not run on Server 2008 R2 or Windows 7.
Silently installs Windows Management Framework 4.0 using chocolatey.
Installs on Windows 7 32-bit or 64-bit. Also installs on Server 2008 R2.
Generates a list of UNC paths to add to exclusion / exceptions lists for Antivirus.

This script will attempt to get psdrive informationand if an error occurs, it will attempt to gather the information using net use. If everything goes well, a list of exceptions will be piped into a gridview to copy into the AV exceptions field.
Creates a Git repository at file path the user specifies.
Function checks to see if git is installed, and if it isn't it installs git. If git is installed, the function then runs git to make a clone of the primary repository located on github.
This will be the name for your local repository.
This will be the address of your origin github repository.
This will be the name for your local repository.
This will be the address of your origin github repository.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a repository at $home\modules\ssscmdlets from the github repository "https://github.com/contoso/sss-cmdlets.git"

maml:description.maml:para: Creates shortcuts corresponding to the proper workstation IDs.
Can either pull shortcut IDs from a CSV, or from a set of IDs provided as a parameter.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Uses Workstation IDs supplied by the -IDName parameter to create icons in the destination folder "i:\icons"
Pulls Workstation IDs from a CSV and publishes them to "D:\icons"

maml:description.maml:para: Renames a computer to its serial number.
Renames the computer by grabbing the serial number off the motherboard and replacing the current computer name.
sets drivemaps to a file share not on the domain through secure string credentials.
when run as part of a script, this allows users to log in using custom credentials. It maps all drive required for internal SSS mission critical file access.
Use full domain credentials for this. ie DOMAIN\USERNAME
Enter in the password here. It's converted to secure string for use with proper credential security within the powershell instance.
Use full domain credentials for this. ie DOMAIN\USERNAME
Enter in the password here. It's converted to secure string for use with proper credential security within the powershell instance.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This CMDlet allows an administrator to quickly set drive maps using individual usernames and passwords to a file share that does not have domain trust. It works best when using GPO Mapped drives is not optimal, like say, when users need to use individual logins different than their domain credentials to access a network drive.

maml:description.maml:para: Pulls the Product key hex value from the motherboard, converts it to ASCII, and pipes it to slmgr.vbs for activation.

This script pulls the product key from a UEFI/Windows 8 motherboard for use in oem key activation in legacy mode. Make sure to Have oa3tool.exe in the same working directory as this script. It is part of Microsoft ADK. Use this script to install 32-bit versions of Windows 8.1 on UEFI OEM machines running in legacy mode. Since activation doesn't occur automatically, manual activation is necessary.
By default, OA3tool.exe should be included in this module package.
By default, OA3tool.exe should be included in this module package.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Paramter points to OA3tool.exe for activation to be run properly.
